The Institute for Cork Board Studies

Est. 2017 by Dr. Agnes Plumley (whereabouts unknown)

"Everything ordinary deserves serious attention."

To whomever has found this page,


I am Dr. Bartholomew Stippleford. I did not build this Institute. Agnes did, at 3am on a Tuesday, because she could not bear the thought that nobody was cataloguing what people pin to their walls. She left me her filing cabinets, her unfinished research, and a conviction I cannot shake: that the cork board is the most honest surface in any room.


I have been carrying this work for seven years now. Some days it feels like holding a door open for someone who may never walk through it. But the door stays open. The filing cabinets remain exactly where Agnes left them. And the work ‚Äî the real, careful, sometimes absurd work of paying attention to what everyone else ignores ‚Äî continues.


‚Äî Dr. B. Stippleford, Acting Director

The Cork Board Census

Now in its sixth year, the Census is the only systematic attempt to quantify what humanity pins up. Participation is voluntary. Accuracy is aspirational. Funding is nonexistent.

3.7 average pins per 100 cm¬≤
43% brass thumbtack (most common type)
12% boards reorganized annually (a crisis)
2.3 yrs median age of oldest pinned item
67% contain at least one expired coupon
1 in 4 boards hold a photo of someone unidentified

Call for Papers

Special Issue: "The Cork Board as Palimpsest: Erasure, Memory, and the Mutable Surface"

The editorial board of Pin & Surface: A Journal of Cork Board Studies invites submissions for our Spring 2027 special issue exploring the cork board as a site of continuous overwriting ‚Äî each new pin an act of revision, each removal an act of forgetting.

  • Deadline: 15 September 2026
  • Word count: 6,000‚Äì10,000 words (footnotes count; they always count)
  • Format: Chicago 17th edition. No exceptions. Agnes was very clear about this.
  • Review: Double-blind. Your pins will be anonymized. The reviewers will not know whose board wept.
  • Queries: submissions@corkboardstudies.org (checked intermittently)

We particularly welcome submissions on: the archaeology of layered notices, the semiotics of pin placement, cork degradation as metaphor, and whether anyone has ever actually read a pinned fire safety notice.

Agnes's unfinished manuscript on this topic was found in her office, 37 pages long, the last sentence mid-clause. We are not publishing it. We are not ready.

Frequently Asked Questions

Compiled from seven years of conference Q&A sessions, hostile email correspondence, and one deeply confusing phone call from a cork supplier in Alentejo.

We understand why this question persists. Burlap-covered fiberboard appears, to the untrained eye, to perform many of the same functions as cork: it accepts pins, it hangs on walls, it accumulates the detritus of organizational intention. But let us be precise.

Cork is harvested from the bark of Quercus suber. It is a living material with a cellular memory ‚Äî literally, the cells retain their honeycomb structure even after decades. Fiberboard is compressed wood pulp. Burlap is jute. Together they form a surface that mimics cork without any of its essential qualities: the give, the grip, the way a pin settles into it with that particular soft resistance.

The Institute's position, formalized in our 2019 white paper "On Surfaces That Pretend," is that burlap-fiberboard is a parallel tradition deserving its own scholarly apparatus.1 We do not consider it cork adjacent. We consider it cork-aspirational. There is an important difference, and Agnes would want us to maintain it.

1 Plumley, A. & Stippleford, B. "On Surfaces That Pretend: A Taxonomic Framework for Pin-Receptive Wall Coverings." Pin & Surface 2(1), 2019, pp. 14‚Äì31.

We do not know. She left the Institute on the evening of March 14, 2021, after a disagreement about pin classification methodology that I will not characterize as heated because Agnes never raised her voice. She simply became more precise. Her last recorded words at the Institute were: "Bartholomew, you are organizing the wrong axis."

Her office remains as she left it. A cork board on the wall holds eleven pins, all empty ‚Äî whatever they held, she took with her. If she is reading this: Agnes, the filing cabinets are exactly where you left them. The methodology question remains open. Your chair is still at the conference table.

The Institute receives no corporate funding from any bulletin board manufacturer, distributor, or lobby group. Our annual budget is approximately what you would spend on a moderately ambitious birthday party. The suggestion that we are beholden to industry interests is both flattering ‚Äî it implies someone cares enough to corrupt us ‚Äî and incorrect.

Full financial disclosure available upon request. Please allow 4‚Äì6 weeks, as I am the entire accounting department.

Portugal produces approximately 49% of the world's cork. This is not a conspiracy; it is a climate. The montado ecosystem of southern Portugal is one of the most biodiverse habitats in Europe, and cork harvesting ‚Äî done by hand, every nine years, without harming the tree ‚Äî is among the most sustainable agricultural practices on Earth.2

There are no cartels. There are families who have harvested cork for generations. If you find this less exciting than a conspiracy, I suggest you have not spent enough time thinking about trees.

2 See: Aronson, J. et al. "Cork Oak Woodlands on the Edge." Island Press, 2009.

No. A digital board cannot hold a thumbtack that your daughter pushed in too hard. It cannot yellow at the edges where sunlight touches it. It cannot bear the small wound of a pin removed ‚Äî that little hole that proves something was once important enough to display. A screen refreshes. Cork remembers.

We do not say this with hostility toward technology. We say it with the calm certainty of people who have spent too long staring at surfaces.

Positions & Resources

Open Positions

Cork Board Archivist ‚Äî Part-time. Bring your own magnifying glass. Must be comfortable with silence and the occasional discovery of personal artifacts that make you question the nature of memory.

Pin Acquisition Specialist ‚Äî Must be willing to travel to cork forests in Portugal. No prior cork experience required, but you should be the kind of person who notices when a thumbtack is missing.

Grief Counselor (Volunteer) ‚Äî For attendees of the Agnes panel. Light duties. Mostly listening.

Resources

Vintage Cork Suppliers Directory ‚Äî 47 verified suppliers across 12 countries. Updated annually, with regret, as some close.

The Pushpin Collector's Quarterly ‚Äî Not our publication, but we read every issue. The Spring 2023 retrospective on colored map pins was, frankly, moving.

Agnes's Annotated Bibliography ‚Äî Incomplete. 412 entries. Her handwriting becomes illegible after entry 390. We have not tried to finish it.
